body:
The `command` variable is coming up as "spork":
https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/5f730b0cb072858ede68ed05f40527fb74539041/lib/rspec/core/configuration.rb#L503

Why do we need to check if the "command" is "rspec"?
I don't remember exactly why, but it was to resolve an issue when running specs using the 'ruby' command.

> I don't remember exactly why, but it was to resolve an issue when running specs using the 'ruby' command.

Here is the commit: https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/commit/e7bb36342b8a3aca2512a0335ea9836780a60605

I am unsure on how to solve this. I can't think of a way to satisfy running specs with `spork`, `rspec`, and `ruby` (whether to include the `default_path` or not).

Requesting backup: @alindeman @myronmarston

Thoughts I've considered:
- Adding `command == 'spork'` as another special case. Feels not so great, but does "work"
- Checking `drb`. However, `drb` is not true in the spork fork (only in the `rspec --drb` process)
- Always defaulting to `default_path` if `files.empty?`. This breaks `rspec/autorun` via `ruby -Ispec spec/test_spec.rb`
- Adding `RSpec::Core::Runner.running_in_drb?` as another special case.

The last option appears to satisfy all three cases:
- `rspec`
- `rspec --drb`
- `ruby -Ispec spec/*_spec.rb`

Thoughts? Is that a reasonable use case for that method? Am I missing anything?

``` ruby
files << default_path if (command == 'rspec' || Runner.running_in_drb?) && default_path && files.empty?
```

What about this?

``` ruby
files << default_path if command != 'ruby' && default_path && files.empty?
```

It sounds like the special case is `ruby`, and it's the one case that should not get a default path.  If so, it makes sense to use it as the special case in the conditional.

This may be obvious to those with more rspec experience but the following works.

rspec spec --drb

@randomutterings right. The problem presented in this issue is that the implicit `default_path` (which is `spec` by default) should make it across DRb, but it doesn't. There is no problem if you're explicit about the path.
I'll see if that works in all the cases I can come up with.

Ah, I remember now. When tests run like `ruby -Ispec spec/.../foo_spec.rb` (via `rspec/autotest`), `$0` is `"spec/.../foo_spec.rb"`.

I actually don't know a way offhand to access `"ruby"` in that scenario. I'll dig, but let me know if anyone has thoughts.

As far as I know there's no way to access the command that invoked the process, ruby's global ($blah) variables don't appear to contain it - https://gist.github.com/3785040#file_ruby_globals.rb, nor do the Object.constant's (ARGV, etc) - https://gist.github.com/3785047#file_ruby_object_constants.rb.

Seems like @alindeman's `Runner.running_in_drb?` suggestion might be the best then, given we can't special case whether we're run from `ruby` or not.
Thanks for the thoughts @caius. Anyone got any other ideas ... or any objections to checking `running_in_drb?`?
